bibl.title: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 25, 1906

div1.p: Gorgas offers his opinion on the organization of the Sanitary Department in the Canal Zone. He also comments on his candidacy for the office of Surgeon General.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, April 25, 1906
div1.opener:
ISTHMIAN CANAL ZONE
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH
----
OFFICE OF CHIEF SANITARY OFFICER
ANCON, C. Z.
April 25th 1906.
My dear Kean,
div1.p:
Yours of April 4th received,
Magoons trip to Washington has
cleared up the atmosphere a good
deal as for as he & I am concerned.

I think that he has found out
that the success of the Sanitary De-
partment has not interfered with
his reputation as governor and that
a technical reputation as a sanita-
rian would not advance his
chances for advancement.

At any rate we have been two
cooing doves since his return.

You probably understand the
present organization of the work
2
shouts as Chairman is really the head.
The government, engineer department,
auditing, purchasing, & pay depart-
ments being subdivisions reporting
directly to him.

I feel pretty sure that we will
have a reorganization as soon as
Congress adjourns. Now I want
one of two things. Either that
the Sanitary Department Bureau
be raised to the plan of the other
departments & report directly to
the chairman, or that the Chief San-
itary Officer be made governor
when Magoon leaves.

There are many good arguments
why the Sanitary Department should
be raised to the planed of the other
3
department. Sanitation is generally recog-
nized as being only second to the
Engineer Department in importance in
the construction of the Canal.

The Chief Sanitary Officers duties
are vastly more intimate with the
Engineers than with the Government.
This most important duty is that
concerning the health of the Engi-
neer laborers. But besides his
duties pertain to enforcing health
measures against the Government,
Auditing, Purchasing & Pay De-
partments. And besides he is
the health officer of Colon & Pan-
ama deriving his authority entirely
from the President of Panama
& outside the jurisdiction of the
U.S. I am trying to point
out that the function of the San-
itary Department are much more
extensive than than those of any
other department, & more important
than those of any other except the
Engineer, & therefor should not be
a bureau & subject to any one of
these. Magoon has had a
resolution passed authorizing
his executive secretary practically
to act as governor in his ab-
sence. Now Reed is just as
nice a fellow & as sensible as
could hold that position, but
I do not think it right or dig-
nified that the Chief Sanitary
Officer for three months should
have to receive orders & all his

5
ISTHMIAN CANAL ZONE
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH
----
OFFICE OF CHIEF SANITARY OFFICER
ANCON, C. Z.
authorizations from a man
in Reeds position.

I have talked over freely to Shouts
this matter of making the Sanitary
Department independent about
as I have written it here. We
approves the idea and gives me
to understand that he will bring
it about if he can.

If the Sanitary Office were
made Governor I think that it
would be an even better solu-
tion. I would then be the head
of a department reporting directly
to the Chairman & besides have
the prestige of governorship be-
6
hind me. Magoon tells me that
he has no definite position ahead of
him, but many things make me think
that he does not expect to stay down
here long. It seems to me that
when the canal gets well under way
we will not be under the lime light
as we have been in the past. In
that case the governorship will not
be as desirable to a man with po-
litical ambitions as it has been in
the past.

I do not know exactly of any
way in which Gen. O Reilly can as-
sist me in these matters, but merely
write to let you know my plans
and what I am driving at, so
that if any opportunity should
come up he can act intelligent-
7
ly with matter.

I have heard nothing whatever
with regard to my candidacy for
the Surgeon Generalcy since I talked
the matter over with Gen. O'Reilly,
now have my views undergone any
change on that subject.

Every thing continues to progress
favorably in the Sanitary De-
partment. No yellow fever
since December 11th and the
health of the force remarkably
good.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, W. C. Gorgas.
